5. Shi Sengyuan, 1. Shi Tandu
Shi Sengyuan, originally surnamed Zhao, was a person from Yingchuan, the descendant of Wei's Minister of Works Yan.
He loved reading books since young.
After receiving full ordination, he specialized in Buddhist doctrines.
He first traveled to Xuzhou and stayed at White Pagoda Temple, where he studied the Satyasiddhi ÅšÄstra and Abhidharma with Sengsong.
In less than three years, his accomplishments surpassed ten years of study, and his wisdom and understanding were renowned far and near.
Sengyuan had a majestic appearance, with a waist circumference of ten feet, a clear and distant demeanor, and a free and easy manner of speaking.
Liu Yin, a recluse, gave up his residence on the mountain to be used as a monastery.
Tandu, Huiji, and Daodeng all studied under Sengyuan.
Hui Ji was also proficient in Saá¹ƒkhya philosophy. Dao Deng was well-versed in the Nirvana Sutra and the Lotus Sutra, and was respected by Emperor Yuan Hong of Wei, becoming famous in the Wei state.
Yuan died in the fifth year of the Wei Taihe era, at the age of sixty-eight, which was the third year of the Jianyuan era of Qi.
Shi Tan Du, originally surnamed Cai, was a person from Jiangling.
From a young age, he was respectful and cautious in conduct, and was known for his adherence to the precepts.
His spiritual faculties were sharp and his insight surpassed that of ordinary people.
Later, he studied in the capital and became well-versed in various scriptures.
He thoroughly explored the subtle and hidden meanings of the Nirvana Sutra, the Lotus Sutra, the Vimalakirti Sutra, and the Large Perfection of Wisdom Sutra, and his thoughts went beyond the words.
Due to a foot injury, he traveled west and arrived in Xuzhou, where he followed Dharma Master Seng Yuan to further study the Satyasiddhi Shastra.
He thus became proficient in this treatise and was unrivaled in his time.
Emperor Yuan Hong of Wei heard of him and invited him with offerings, sending envoys to request his presence.
After arriving in Pingcheng, he extensively opened lecture sessions.
He personally managed and savored the lectures, greatly promoting respect and attendance.
Thus, he stayed in the Wei capital, and the Dharma teachings continued. More than a thousand students came from afar.
He passed away in the Wei state in the thirteenth year of the Taihe era, which was the sixth year of the Yongming era in the Southern Qi dynasty.
He composed an eight-fascicle commentary on the great meaning of the Satyasiddhi ÅšÄstra, which was widely circulated in the north.
Shi Daohui, Shi Daohui, whose surname was Wang, was a person from Yuzhang who lived in Jianye.
At the age of eleven, he left home to become a disciple of Sengyuan and stayed at Lingyao Temple.

When he was fourteen, he read the Collection of Huiyuan of Mount Lu and sighed with emotion, regretting that he was born too late. He then traveled a thousand li upstream with his friend Zhisun to visit Huiyuan's remaining traces. He stayed at Xishan Temple on Mount Lu for three years and returned to the capital city.
At that time, the king sometimes discussed the meaning of the three characteristics with a large assembly of learned monks.
At that time, Hui was seventeen years old. He then asked several rounds of questions, with profound words and orderly explanations.
Everyone marveled at him.
Later, he studied under the two Dharma masters Meng and Bin.
Meng once lectured on the Satyasiddhi-Å›Ästra.
Zhang Rong raised questions repeatedly.
Meng said he was unwell and could not handle many, so he ordered Hui to answer them.
Zhang Rong, because Hui was young, had some feelings of contempt.
Hui took advantage of the situation to subdue him, and his words always reached the principle. He responded back and forth, with plenty of leeway.
He was good at Mahayana and understood Abhidharma. His lectures continued, and his students were very numerous.
He classified the meanings and categories, and began to make chapters and sections.
Chu Cheng and Xie Chaozong were famous at that time, and they were all respected.
Hui, because his mother was old, wanted to provide for her. He then moved to rest at Zhuangyan Temple.
Her mother, out of pity for her determination, allowed her to leave home and practice the Way, and donated the house for the benefit of others, establishing a nunnery.
Hui died in the third year of the Jianyuan era of the Qi dynasty, at the age of thirty-one.
At the time of her death, she called for her yak-tail fan and handed it to her friend Zhi Shun.
Shun lamented:
Such a person, not even reaching forty years old, it is a pity.
He then placed the yak-tail fan inside the coffin and had her interred.
She was buried on the southern side of Mount Zhong.
Xie Chaozong of Chen Prefecture wrote the inscription for her stele.
At that time, Zhuangyan also had Xuanqu and Sengda, who were both renowned for their learning and understanding.
Xuanqu was well-versed in various sutras and was proficient in both internal and external [matters], but he was especially good at debates, and his demeanor was delightful.
Sengda had white hair when he was young, and people called him White-haired Sengda. He was also well-versed in various scriptures and was especially skilled in correspondence.
But he was stubborn and offended others, and was expelled to Changsha.
4. Shi Seng Zhong, Shi Seng Zhong, whose surname was Sun, was a person from Lu Jun.
He left home at the age of sixteen and lived in poverty while practicing the Way.
Once he went to Shou Chun, and Master Dao saw him and found him extraordinary.
Qiao Jun Wang Ye respected his character and provided him with the four necessities.
Later, he requested to lecture on the Hundred Treatises.
Dao went to listen to it and said to others:
The young are indeed to be feared, as the saying goes.
Zhong was wonderful at Cheng Shi, the Three Treatises, Nirvana, Shi Di and so on.
Later he traveled south to the capital and stayed at Zhong Xing Temple.
In the beginning of Yong Ming, Wei envoy Li Dao Gu came to pay tribute and met him in the temple.
The Emperor considered that Zhong had virtue and fame, and ordered him to respond.
They went back and forth for a while, and his words were never misplaced. The sun was a little late, and Zhong did not eat.
Gu said:
Why don't you eat?
Zhong said:
The ancient Buddhas' way is to not eat after noon.
He insisted:
Why are you a Å›rÄvaka?
Zhong said:
For those who should be liberated by the Å›rÄvakas, I manifest as a Å›rÄvaka.
At that time, people considered it a famous answer.
After that, he roamed around lecturing, and those who listened to him formed a crowd.
The Crown Prince Wenhui of the Qi dynasty and Prince Wenxuan of Jingling repeatedly invited him to face south.
He died in the seventh year of Yongming of the Qi dynasty, at the age of sixty.

At that time, those who were equal in fame and virtue to Zhong were Tan Xian, Tan Qian, Sengbiao, Sengzui, Mindai, Sengbao, and others. They were all good at sutra and treatise, and were respected by Wenxuan, and they held lecture sessions in turn.
Shi Daosheng, Shi Daosheng, whose surname was Zhu, was a person from the state of Pei.
He left home at a young age and was diligent in learning. He was good at the Nirvana Sutra and the VimalakÄ«rti Sutra, and was also proficient in the Book of Changes.
When he first resided in Xiangzhou, Emperor Ming of the Liu Song dynasty heard of him and ordered him to the capital, where he stayed at Pengcheng Temple.
Xie Chaozong met him once and subsequently respected him as his teacher.
He then wrote the Treatise on the Correspondence of Heaven and Earth and the Treatise on the Origin of Life and Death.
Later, he rested at Tianbao Temple. Emperor Gao of the Qi dynasty ordered him to replace Tandu as the head of the monks.
Danyang Yin Shen Wenzhi, who originally followed Huang-Lao, resented and slandered the Buddha.

He then established the Buddhist Bureau and held monks accountable. He wanted to select and dismiss monks and nuns. Because Sheng had made great contributions in leading, the matter was peacefully put to rest.
Later, Wenzhi held a gathering at Tianbao and ordered Lu Xiujing to discuss with Sheng.
Since Sheng had a strong understanding of principles and was eloquent, he bantered back and forth without a moment's pause.
Xiujing was unable to express his intentions and left in embarrassment.
Sheng died in the Yongming era of the Qi dynasty, at over sixty years old.
Shi Hongchong of Liangzhou was a person from Liangzhou.
From a young age, he had ambition and strength, and was well-versed in Zhuangzi, Laozi, and the sutras and vinaya.
At the end of the Daming era, he crossed the river and initially stayed at Duobao Temple.
He was good at asking difficult questions, and many of the pioneers were defeated by him.
Later, he himself opened a Dharma lecture, and the sharp questions came one after another.
Since Chong had already deeply understood the profound principles and his eloquence was as free as the wind, he could resolve doubts and clear away obstructions without any hesitation.
Whenever he lectured on the Lotus Sutra and the Ten Grounds, the audience filled the hall. The Minister of Education and the Prince of Wenxian of Jiangxia, Yigong, deeply respected him.
When Emperor Ming ascended the throne, he established Xianggong Temple and invited Chong to be the leader. Thus, he moved there.
At that time, there was also the monk Fashan at Xianggong, who was also intelligent and had the power of thought. He was on par with Chong.
Chong passed away during the Yongming era of the Qi dynasty, at the age of 72.
He also wrote commentaries on the MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«'s Questions on Bodhi SÅ«tra and the ÅšÅ«raá¹ƒgama SÅ«tra.
Shi Zilin Shi Zilin, from Gaochang, initially became a monk under Master Liang.

From a young age, he revered principles and loved learning. He carried scriptures to Chang'an and traveled with his staff to the Jiang and Yu regions, extensively collecting various scriptures, and was particularly skilled in the Miscellaneous Mind treatise.
When Master Liang was expelled, all twelve of his disciples followed him to the borderlands.
Zilin then rested his steps in Panyu and spread the teachings in the Haiguo region.
In the early years of the Song and Ming dynasties, he was ordered to be provided with funds and sent to the capital, where he stayed at Lingji Temple.
He lectured continuously, and his disciples formed a large group. He clarified the two truths, which have three different schools.
At that time, Zhou Yong of Runan also wrote the Treatise on the Three Schools, which agreed with Zilin's ideas, and he was deeply delighted. He then wrote a letter to Yong, saying:

Recently I heard that the donor has narrated the new meaning of the two truths and presented the acceptance and rejection of the three schools, with a voice different from the constant precepts. Although the gift is not as swift as my humble thoughts, I consider that the principle of the world is only this to be correct.
If it is not like this, it is not principle.
Therefore, I encourage you to quickly write it down.
Recently I have seen those who come and go, hearing that the treatise has already been completed, and it is widely circulated, which is especially heavy.

Moreover, I have received the donor's concern that establishing the extraordinary may violate the assembly of learners, and although the treatise is completed, it may not necessarily be published. Hearing this, I am afraid and cannot help but lie down.

The purport of this meaning seems not to be the initial opening, and the wonderful sound is cut off for sixty-seven years. The principle is lofty and beyond the usual rhyme, and no one can transmit it.
When I was twenty years old, I was fortunate enough to obtain this meaning.
I always considered that relying on this subtle understanding, I could attain the Way.
I secretly rejoiced every time, not sharing it with others.
The young people who saw the elders of Chang'an often said that this was the old meaning in Guanzhong.
When the Dharma assembly was in full swing, there were not many people who could deeply understand this principle.
Since it violated common sense, later generations who listened and received it became very few;
There were almost no people who transmitted it to Jiangdong.

Since I held the whisk for more than forty years, lecturing in the east and west, mistakenly honored by the times, the other doctrinal systems were mostly seen in the classics, but only this path, no one, black or white, could attain it.

I have been sick for many years, and now I am at the end of my illness. Moreover, my life is coming to an end, and I will soon return to the west. Looking back, this path will be forever cut off from now on.
The patron's inspiration is without precedent, creating something beyond the world, not expecting this sound to enter the ears.
I am both delighted and comforted, truly beyond description.
Establishing this meaning will ensure that the Dharma lamp has an end, and this is the foremost merit of truly practicing the Way.
Even if one were to offer one's country, city, wife, and children to the Buddha and the Sangha, the blessings and benefits would not be able to surpass this.
Since you have fortunately been able to expound it, I imagine you will widely proclaim it, so that those who appreciate it may see it.
In discussing the principles of the Dharma, one should not yield to others out of politeness. How can one be concerned with the opinions of the crowd and stifle the extraordinary meaning?
If this treatise has already been completed and is then suddenly put aside, I fear that when donors come, this may become a major obstacle for them.
My previous words were sincere, and they were not spoken in jest.ğŸ”½I imagine you will then copy a copy and give it to me, so that I can take it back to the west and spread it everywhere.
I have been slightly unwell recently, so I entered the mountains to write this letter. I deeply look forward to your reply.
Thus, [Hui]yong wrote the treatise.
Therefore, the purport of the three schools has been transmitted and expounded until today.
Lin was eight feet tall, with a majestic appearance. When he ascended the seat and roared, his eloquence flowed like a river.
Later, he declined and returned to Gaochang.
He died in the fifth year of the Yongming era of the Qi dynasty, at the age of seventy-nine.
He wrote the Treatise on the Two Truths, the Record of the Abhidharma-vibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra, and annotated the Twelve Gates Treatise and the Middle Treatise, etc.
Shi Fayuan, Shi Fayuan, whose surname was Xin, was a person from Longxi, a descendant of Xin Pi.
His elder brother Yuan Ming served the Wei Dynasty as a Grand Minister.
His second elder brother, Fayue, was also a monk.
He understood sutras and treatises, and also mathematics, and served as the teacher of the Rui Rui state, with a salary of three thousand households.
Fayuan was broad-minded and extraordinary from a young age. When he saw poor people on the road, he would take off his clothes to give to them.
When he first left home, he served the Liangzhou monk Zhu Huikai.
Huikai had a virtuous and spiritual nature, and people of the time said he had attained the first fruit.
Huikai said to Fayuan:
If your understanding is like this, you will surely be able to lead and transform the followers. You should compete in learning widely, and not be content with personal goodness.
Thereupon, he took leave and went traveling to study, passing through Yan and Zhao, going and coming between Ye and Luoyang.
He encountered the Hu bandits running rampant, and the Guannei and Longyou regions in turmoil, but Yuan dared to take risks and tread on danger, without slacking in his studies.
In the 15th year of Yuanjia, he returned to Liangzhou, then proceeded to Chengdu, and later went east to Jianye, following Daofang Huiguan as his teacher.
He was devoted to the Mahayana, and also studied various philosophical theories.
He also read widely in the classics and histories.
Later, he entered Mount Lu, guarding the stillness and savoring meditation, contemplating the five gates and immersing his mind in the three contemplations.
After a while, Prefect Yuden invited him out of the mountain to lecture.

Later, when Emperor Wen was looking for those who could expound the meaning of Sheng Gong's sudden enlightenment, he ordered him to the capital to reiterate the doctrine of sudden enlightenment in the Song dynasty.
He Shangzhi heard of this and sighed:
I always thought that after Master Sheng passed away, his subtle teachings would be forever lost.
Today, I have heard discussions beyond the ordinary, which can be said to be the heavens not having lost his writings.
The emperor ordered him to be the teacher of the five precepts for Prince Shao of Nanping.
When Emperor Xiaowu ascended the throne, he ordered him to be a friend of Prince Shang of Xiyang.
He declined on the grounds of illness, and after a long time, he was excused.
He then lived in seclusion on Fang Mountain, annotating the Shengman Sutra and the Weimishi Sutra.
In the gaps between discussions, he sometimes talked about the Book of Filial Piety and Mourning Garments.
Later, Tianbao was rebuilt, and he was invited to live there. He then left the mountain and entered the city, becoming the leader of the temple network.
Prefect Wang Jingwen went to visit him, and just happened to be listening to a lecture on Mourning Garments. He discussed several points and withdrew in praise.
When Emperor Ming built the new Xiang Palace, he greatly opened lecture halls and carefully selected outstanding monks. He ordered Master Yuan to be the Dharma master.
The emperor then descended to the Dharma seat, and officials gathered at the seat. The splendor of the time, those who saw it were honored by it.
Later, Qi Wenhui again invited him to reside at Linggen, so he moved to that temple.
Taiwei Wang Jian had no miscellaneous friends, but only treated Yuan as his teacher, and his letters and words were full of respect.
In the seventh year of Yongming of Qi, he died at the age of eighty-one.
At that time, there were also Fachang and Zhixing at Linggen Temple, who were both well-versed in sutras and treatises, and often lectured.
Fachang was especially good at dramatic talks, which were feared by the craftsmen of the time.
But his nature was very rigid and did not conform to worldly customs.
Shi Xuangchang, whose surname was Zhao, was from Jincheng, Hexi.
When he was young, his family was exterminated by the Hu captives, and the disaster was about to befall Xuangchang. The leader of the captives saw Xuangchang and stopped them, saying:
This child's eyes shoot out, he is no ordinary child.
He was thus spared, and went to Liangzhou to become a monk.
His original name was Huizhi, but later he met Xuan Gao and became his disciple.
Gao always admired him and always discussed matters with him. He then changed his name to Xuan Chang, to express the meaning of entrustment.
Later, the brutal invaders destroyed Buddhism and harmed the monks, but only Chang was able to escape.

On the seventeenth day of the intercalary fifth month in the twenty-second year of the Yuanjia era, he left Pingcheng and passed through Daijun and Shanggu, crossed the Taihang Mountains to the east, passed through Youzhou and Jizhou, and turned south to reach Mengjin.
He only held a bundle of willow branches in his hand and a handful of scallion leaves.
The pursuers were about to catch up with him, so he struck the sand with the willow branches.
The sand rose and the sky darkened, and the riders and horses could not move forward.

After a while, the sand settled and the riders arrived again. He then threw himself into the river, only using scallion leaves in his nostrils to breathe and cross the water. On the first day of the eighth month, he reached Yangzhou.
He thoroughly understood the scriptures and vinaya, deeply penetrated the essentials of Chan, and his predictions of good and bad fortune were all true.
He was well-versed in the classics and histories.
As for worldly skills and miscellaneous abilities, there were few that he was not proficient in.
Originally, the vast text and meaning of the Huayan Sutra had never been expounded since ancient times.
Chong then exhausted his thoughts to study and explore, comparing chapters and sentences.
The transmission and lecturing of the sutra began with Chong.
He was also good at the Three Treatises and was revered by learners.
Emperor Wen of the Song Dynasty deeply admired and respected him, inviting him to be the teacher of the crown prince, but he firmly declined three times.
His disciples said to him:
The Dharma Master is about to spread the Way and benefit beings, widely propagating the teachings.
Now the emperor has humbled himself to invite you, and the crown prince has respectfully thought of you with courtesy. If the Way is promoted by the sage king, the four seas will return to virtue.
Now you stubbornly refuse, is this not the way of the hearers?
Chong said:
This can be discussed with the wise, but it is difficult to speak of it with ordinary people.
Only then did he know that the previous realization was due to the matter of the beginning of the great initial eon.
Since then, he has moved and stayed in Jingzhou, residing at Changsha Temple.
At that time, the monk Gongde Zhi published the Sutra of Buddha Mindfulness Samadhi, etc., and Chang corrected the text and the meaning of the words was elegant and touching.
Moreover, he extended his hand to emit fragrance and flowing water from his palm, which was beyond comprehension.
Until the end of the Song Dynasty, he then sailed far away to Chengdu in the west.
He first stayed at Dashi Temple, where he painted sixteen divine images such as Vajrapaá¹‡i.

In the third year of Shengming, he traveled to the western border again, observing the Min Mountains. He saw Qihou Mountain in the northern area of Guangyang County in Min Mountain Prefecture, and finally had the intention to end his life there.
He then relied on the cliffs and valleys, and made a grass hut.
His disciple Faqi saw a divine person riding a horse, wearing a blue single garment, circling the mountain once, and then showing the place to build the pagoda.
On the twenty-third day of the fourth month in the first year of the Jianyuan era of the Qi dynasty.
He erected a flagpole and built a temple, named Qiheng, which was the very day when Emperor Taizu of the Qi dynasty received the imperial decree.
The timing of heaven and the affairs of people, a thousand miles apart, coincided.
At that time, Fu Yan was the Western Capital of Chengdu, admiring the wind and rules, treating him with teacher's respect.
After Chang established the temple, he wrote a letter to Yan, saying:

I have been staying in Jingzhou for many years, and my illness has accumulated with age. I am disgusted by the noise of people, so I have traveled far to the Min River region and settled on this hill.
It is east of Guangyang, a thousand steps away from the city.

Stretching long and winding, it connects the mountain ranges and crosses the four streams, spans the five peaks, embraces the city and the town, overlooks the three directions, with hills behind and mountains in the back, and looks far into the nine currents. On the twenty-third day of the fourth month last year, the work began with the laying of the foundation.
In the previous winter, I visited and heard that day was the day when Your Majesty ascended the throne.

I have heard that when the Way matches the Great Ultimate, auspicious omens appear on their own, and when virtue is equal to the Two Principles, spiritual responses must be manifested. Therefore, the River and Luo had the signs of the Zhou dynasty, and the spiritual stone indicated the omen of the Great Jin.
I humbly believe that the confirmation of this mountain is not it the spiritual response of the Qi Emperor?
The donor's devotion to the country is deep, so much so that the time and signs are in accord, unable to forget the mind, how could he neglect the matter?
I then wrote a chapter on the Praise of the Mountain to express my foolish thoughts.
The praise says:
The lofty Qi Mountain, born from the netherworld.
The auspicious signs of the past were hidden, and the imperial title was still bright.
The sacred abode was lofty, and the reign name was auspicious.
The mountain roots were flat with clouds, and the peaks and cliffs were even with mist.
The temple was planned on the cliff, and the sutra was compiled beyond the mountain range.
On the day the construction began, the dragon flew to the purple court.
The Way was equal to the two polarities, and the four seas were equally clear.
The reign that lasts until the end of heaven, the mountain virtue manifests the spirit.
Yan then fully reported it to the emperor.
The emperor decreed that one hundred households be exempted to provide for his salary.
Qi's Cavalry General and Prince of Yuzhang, Yi, who was stationed in Jingxia, sent an envoy to request him.
The lord of Tugu Hun in Henan, who admired him from afar, rode hundreds of horses to welcome him at Qishan.
As he had already gone east, they did not meet.
When Qi's martial emperor ascended the throne, the Minister of Education and Prince Wenxuan initiated the return to the capital from Jiangling.
The Crown Prince of Wenhui also sent an envoy to request him. As the imperial decree was repeated, he could not refuse.
He then sailed east, but fell ill on the way and arrived in the capital with an illness. The crowd stopped and looked up to him, and he stayed at Linggen Temple.
After a short time, he passed away at the age of sixty-nine.
This year, on the sixteenth day of the eleventh month in the second year of Yongming in the Qi dynasty, he was buried in front of Dulon Mountain on Zhong Mountain.
The Prince of Linchuan established a stele, and Zhou Yong of Runan wrote the inscription.
Shi Sengyuan, Shi Sengyuan, whose surname was Huang, was a person from Chonghe in Bohai.
His ancestors were the Huangfu clan of Beidi, who fled to the coast to avoid danger, so they removed fu and kept huang.
Sengyuan was happy with the Way from a young age. At the age of sixteen, he wanted to leave home, but his parents did not allow it.
So he fasted, repented, and recited scriptures day and night without stopping. At the age of eighteen, he finally got to enter the Way.
At that time, there was a monk named Daohui, who was highly talented and virtuous, and his reputation covered the seas and mountains.
Sengyuan followed him to study and became proficient in various theories, mastering the Mahayana and Hinayana teachings.
During the Daming period of the Liu Song dynasty, he crossed the river and stayed at Pengcheng Temple.
During the Shengming period, he established a monastery on Niuluo Mountain in Xiao Danyang, named Longyuan.
At the age of thirty-one, Yuan started lecturing at Sun Tai Temple in Qingzhou.
His speech was clear and his demeanor was elegant. More than four hundred people in attendance were all impressed.
Wang Sengda of Langya was a talented and noble person of the time. He highly respected Yuan's character and invited him to stay at Zhongzao Temple.
Yuan helped the poor and needy, but he did not keep any wealth for himself.
There was a monk named Xuan Shaojie who often gave him gold and silk,
but Yuan declined and did not accept them.
Once, when he was walking in Qingyuan, he heard that there were people in the neighborhood who had contracted a contagious disease. He felt pity and went to see them.
He saw several people who were dead and sick, and no one dared to approach them. Yuan felt even more grief and stayed there, unable to leave.
He then went out to beg for alms, collected the dead bodies, and comforted the living. His kindness was like that of a relative.

Prince Xiao of Xin'an in the Song dynasty, on behalf of his deceased mother, Empress Dowager Yin, built Xin'an Temple. The emperor ordered the selection of three prefectures to invite eminent scholars.
Far, together with Fayao of Mount Xiao and Xian Liang of Nanxi, were all summoned. They all recommended Far as the leader.
In the ninth month of the sixth year of Daming, the authorities reported:
We have heard that the lofty and secluded throne is not for the sake of grandeur;
Kneeling with fists clenched and lying prone is not just for respect and obedience.
It is to clearly uphold the four norms and establish the eight prohibitions.

Therefore, although Confucianism and Dharma have different branches and names and Mohist teachings have different streams, as far as honoring the ruler and respecting the elders, there is no deviation.
Only the teachings of Buddhism, which originated from the Dragon Descendant,
Have profound principles and subtle words that are lost in the distance. Clinging to the texts obscures the Way, and in the end, it becomes more and more prevalent.
Thus, they violate the norms and treat the ruler and elders with contempt.
They lose the wonderful traces of adapting to the world and are confused about the profound beauty of the creation and transformation.
The Buddha's teachings take humility and frugality as self-cultivation, and kindness and sincerity as the way.
The bhiká¹£u Aniruddha, when encountering people, would definitely bow.
MaudgalyÄyana, a monk, would pay respect to the elderly.ğŸ”½How could there be a situation where one bows to the four groups but not to one's parents;
where one bows to the elders in the monastic community but not to the emperor?
Therefore, in the Xiankang era, the proposal was first made, and in the Yuanxing era, it was carried out, but the matter was limited to a biased faction, and the way was diminished to a lesser part.
Now, the vast source is far-reaching, and all rivers look up to it as a mirror. The nine immortals offer treasures, and hundreds of spirits follow their duties.
Yet within the capital, there are people who do not submit;
between the steps and seats, there are guests who extend their resistance to paying respect.
I fear this is not the way to clarify the model of the wind and show the auspicious pattern.
We ministers have discussed and think that Å›ramaá¹‡as should all show utmost sincerity and respect when meeting.
If they follow their original customs, then the court will have an orderly hierarchy, and the principle will be extended far and wide.
Although the Emperor had some faith in the Dharma, he had long been arrogant and indulgent, so on the day the memorial was presented, the edict approved it.
Yuan sighed and said:
I am a shaven-headed monk who originally left home to seek the Way. What does it have to do with the emperor?
On that very day, he excused himself due to illness and then hid his traces on Mount Dinglin.
When the Jinghe period arrived, this decree was again suspended and they returned to following the old regulations.
When Emperor Ming of the Liu Song Dynasty ascended the throne, he invited Yuan to be his teacher, but he was ultimately unable to do so.
After that, guests who lived in seclusion in the mountains and scholars who were aloof from the world and lofty like clouds all flocked to the mountain gate and paid respect in the meditation hall.
He Dian of Mount Lu, Zhou Yong of Runan, Ming Seng Shao of Qizhou, Wu Bao of Puyang, and Zhang Rong of Wuguo all threw themselves at his feet and consulted him on the precepts.

Later, Prince Jing of Jianping of the Liu Song Dynasty said that Qixuan Temple was established by the previous king, and since they were people outside of the temple, he wanted to invite Yuan to live there.
He earnestly invited him three times, but he still did not come down the mountain.
When Emperor Taizu of the Qi dynasty was about to ascend the throne, he entered the mountain to seek Huiyuan.
Huiyuan firmly declined, saying he was old and sick, and his feet did not touch the floor.
Emperor Taizu himself descended to pay respects and inquired in detail.
After ascending the throne, he again traveled in a grand procession to pay respects. He was about to visit Huiyuan's room.
The room was too small to accommodate the carriage and canopy.

In the Western Xia, the Dharma wheel is not interrupted, and it is all due to Master Hui!
Zhang Chang of the State of Wu traveled to the West and visited Hui to request friendship with him.
In the beginning of the Qi dynasty, he was ordered to be the leader of monks in Jingzhou.
His demeanor was elegant and he harmonized with the Way, guiding the world and benefiting it, with his reputation reaching far and near.
When he was old, he always rode in a sedan chair to attend lectures.
The onlookers called him the bald-headed official.
He was contemporary with Xuan Chang, and people of the time called them the Two Black-robed Geniuses.
He died in the fourth year of Yongming in the Qi dynasty, at the age of seventy-nine.
Later, there was Shi Hui Chang, who was also upright by nature. He succeeded Hui as the leader of the monks and continued to make achievements.
Shi Xiu, a disciple of Hui, was also known for his learning and diligence. He died of a blood disease.
Shi Seng Rou, whose surname was Tao, was a person from Dan Yang.
He was pure and clean since childhood, and had the determination to leave the dust.
At the age of nine, he traveled and studied with his uncle.
His family was poor for generations, and even coarse food was not available, but his determination was firm, and he did not change in the face of poverty.
Later, he became a monk and was a disciple of Hong Cheng.
Cheng's surname was LÃ¼, and he was a person from Lin Wei in Luoyang. He was well-versed in sutras and treatises, and his reputation was well-known early on.
After Seng Rou accepted him as his teacher, he diligently studied the precepts, and thoroughly understood meditation and wisdom.
He thoroughly penetrated the profound sources and completely understood the essential points of the various scriptures and treatises, both large and small, of the Fangdeng school.
When he reached the age of twenty, he ascended the lecture seat.
The famous guests of the generation all bowed to him as their teacher.
Later, he traveled east to Yuxue and met with Dharma Master Huiji, who invited him to stay by the city for one summer to lecture and discuss.
Later, he entered Mount Bai in Shan and stayed at Lingjiu Temple.
The night before his arrival, the monk Sengxu dreamed of divine beings with vermilion banners and white armor filling the mountain and coming out.
Sengxu asked the reason:
They replied,
The Dharma Master is about to enter, so we come out to welcome him.
The next morning, he waited for the person, and sure enough, Rou arrived.
He then swept and decorated the mountain gate, with the intention of staying there forever.
He expounded the sutras and followed the teachings, and there were as many students as the trees in a forest.
When Emperor Taizu of the Qi dynasty started his enterprise and when Emperor Shizu succeeded to the throne, they all established monasteries and sought out virtuous scholars.
Because Sengrou had a reputation, he was summoned every year.
The kings of the Wenxuan lineage invited him twice, so he went to the capital again.
He stayed at Dinglin Temple, personally serving as the leader.
The people from the four directions admired and respected him, and both humans and gods praised him.
Both Wenhui and Wenxuan bowed to him as their teacher.
Sengrou upheld virtue and occupied the position, not refusing it.
He always vowed to be reborn in the Pure Land.
Whenever the sun set in the west, he would always frown and put his palms together.
On the day of his death, his body had no other ailments, he only told his disciples:
I should go.
He then spread out a mat on the ground, faced west, devoutly paid homage, and suddenly passed away.
This was the first year of the Yanheng era, and he was sixty-four years old.
He was buried to the south of the mountain.

The Å›ramaá¹‡a Shi Sengyou lived in the mountains with Sengrou since they were young, staying together for many years. He often received his teachings and listened to the Dharma flavor. He erected a stele at the grave site.
Liu Xie of Dongguan composed the text.
Seng Shao, a disciple of Rou, was also upright and had academic achievements.
At that time, at Shanzhi Temple on Zhong Mountain, there were also Seng Bao and Hui Xi, who were both outstanding from a young age and had a high reputation from childhood.
However, their beautiful deeds were not accomplished, and they passed away one after another at an early age.
Seng Bao wrote the Seven Profound Discussions, which is circulated in the world today.
Shi Hui Ji, Shi Hui Ji, whose surname was Ou, was from Qian Tang in Wu Guo.
From a young age, his spirit was outstanding, and his understanding surpassed others. He first followed Dharma Master Hui Yi of Qi Huan.
When he was fifteen years old, Hui Yi praised his spiritual appearance and informed Emperor Wen of the Song Dynasty, requesting to ordain him to leave the household life.
Emperor Wen met with him and found him to be trustworthy. He then ordered a ceremony to be held at Qi Huan Temple for him to leave the household life.
The emperor personally visited the temple, and the officials and nobles must have gathered.
After Hui Ji took refuge in the Dharma gate, he practiced diligently and vigorously, studying both day and night, and had a thorough understanding of the various scriptures.
Later, a Western Dharma master named Saá¹ƒghabhadra, who promoted and praised Chan and the precepts, came to the Song territory.
Yi then ordered Ji to enter the room and serve him.
When Ji was twenty years old, he went to Cai Prefecture to receive full ordination.
Saá¹ƒghabhadra said to Ji:
You will be the king of the Way in Jiangdong. You don't need to stay in the capital for a long time.
Thus, for four or five years, he traveled to lecture halls and visited many teachers.

He was good at the Small Treatise, the Lotus Sutra, the Sutra of the Auspicious Appearances of the Bodhisattva, the Sutra of the Profound Meaning, the Sutra of the Diamond PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ, and the Sutra of Queen ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ.
He all contemplated the profound principles and penetrated the subtle and profound.
He compared chapters and phrases, and his eloquence flowed through the ages.

Master Ji's wisdom and meaning were already the object of respect for others. His Way ruled the land of Jing, and monks and laypeople took refuge in him. He received abundant offerings. Because Ji's noble virtue was worthy of praise, he took him with him to live together.
After Yi's death, the miscellaneous belongings almost filled a million.
He should have received half of the foundation, but he gave it all as blessings, only taking coarse robes and a bowl, and returned east. He stayed at Xianming Temple in Qiantang.
Soon, he went to Kuaiji and stayed at Fahua Temple in Shanyin.
Students of higher learning followed him to ask about the Way.
Thus, he traveled all over the three Wu regions, expounding the scriptures and teachings. More than a thousand students came to study.
Emperor Taizong of the Song sent envoys to invite him, but he declined on the grounds of illness.
In the Yuanhui period, he was again summoned by imperial edict.
When he first set out, he passed the Zhe River, but he became ill again and returned. He then established Baolin Temple on Mount Gui in Kuaiji.
He personally stacked bricks and stones, directing the work himself. The temple was built on a steep cliff, with an exquisite mountain-like design.
It was initially built with three stories, but the craftsmen were a bit clumsy. Later, it was struck by lightning and destroyed.
He further added decorations and finally perfected its beauty.
Ji once dreamed of Samantabhadra and requested him to be his preceptor.

After the temple was completed, he made images of Samantabhadra and a six-tusked white elephant, and held a three-week repentance ritual in the Precious Grove. Officials and laypeople gathered in large numbers, offering gifts one after another.
Later, when Zhou Yong was in charge of Shan, he invited Ji to give lectures.
Since Yong had already studied and deeply understood the Buddha's teachings, when he met Ji and investigated with him, there were new insights every day.
Liu Hean and Zhang Rong both showed him the respect of a teacher and revered his teachings.
The Minister of Education, Prince Wenxuan, admired his virtue from afar and wrote sincere letters to him, asking about the main points of the Lotus Sutra.
Ji then wrote a commentary on the Lotus Sutra in three fascicles.
He also composed a preface to the Gate of Meanings in thirty-three sections, briefly explaining the meaning of skillful means and reconciling the two teachings of emptiness and existence;
and annotated the Sutra of the Buddha's Last Teachings, which are all circulated in the world.
Since Ji's virtue extended to the three Wu regions and his reputation reached throughout the country, he was ordered to be the leader of the monks, in charge of ten cities.
It was the beginning of the position of monastic registrar in the Eastern Land.
Thus, he leisurely expounded the Way, instructing in Chan and wisdom, and those from the four directions followed the wind, and the five groups of disciples submitted.
Ji's nature was stern but able to be gentle, his temperament clear yet respectful, so those who were his disciples all trembled in his presence.
In the third year of Jianwu of the Qi dynasty, in the eleventh month of winter, he passed away at a temple by the city, at the age of eighty-five.
At first, when Ji was seriously ill, his disciples dreamed of several Indian monks all sitting on the steps.
They asked where they came from, and they replied:
We come from the country of Mahayana to welcome Master Ji.
After several days, he passed away, and was buried on the south of Mount Fahua.
He Yin, the Minister of Lujiang, wrote a stele inscription at Baolin Temple, inscribing his remaining virtues.
Ji's disciples Sengxing, Huixu, and Daohui all had excellent academic achievements, and in turn expounded the teachings, each leading their disciples, continuing the previous path.
Later, a monk named Huiliang took over the position of the head of the monks.
After Huiliang passed away, the next was monk Huiyong.
Huiyong had an extraordinary appearance and elegant demeanor, and his virtue and conduct were pure and strict. He was also well-versed in various sutras and often gave lectures.
After Huiyong, the next was monk Huishen, who was also a disciple of Ji.ğŸ”½Huishen and his classmate Fuhong were both respected for their pure and strict observance of the precepts.
After Huishen, the next was monk Tanyou, who was also prudent and had a sense of responsibility.
Shi Huici, Shi Huici, whose surname was Yin, was a person from Jizhou.
He first became a monk and was a disciple of Zhiqin.
Later, he met Shi Fachuan of Xuzhou, who was renowned for his understanding of the time. Zhiqin then entrusted Huici to him.
He then followed Fachuan to Jingkou and stayed at Zhulin Temple.
At the age of fifteen, he followed Fachuan back to Pengcheng.
Although he was still a novice, he was never tired of studying.
His clear understanding and comprehensive grasp were extraordinary and outstanding.
At the age of eighteen, he understood and mastered the sutras and treatises, and his fame spread throughout the Xu region.
Until he received full ordination, his conduct became increasingly profound.
He frequently lectured on the Satyasiddhi-Å›Ästra and the Three Treatises.
During the Daming period, he left for the capital and stayed at Xie Temple.
Until the end of the Song Dynasty and the beginning of the Qi Dynasty, his followers gradually increased. Whenever he set up a lecture seat, laypeople and monks would rush to attend.
Monks Zhizang, Sengmin, and Fayun, who were all young and brilliant, with a natural talent for wisdom, all studied under him.
Wenhui and Wenxuan both respected him as their teacher and provided him with the four necessities.
In the eighth year of the Yongming era, he lectured on the Satyasiddhi-Å›Ästra.
When he reached the chapter on refuting the existence of external objects, he suddenly passed away. He was fifty-seven years old.
At that time, Sengbao and Sengzhi of Xie Temple, Fajin, Senghxiang, Sengem, Fabao, and Huitiao of Changä¹ Temple were all outstanding and wise people of the generation, respected by the public.
Shi Huilong, whose surname was Cheng, was a person from Yangping.
He lived in poverty as a youth, without teachers or friends for learning, yet he was self-awakened. At the age of twenty-three, he finally became a monk.
For more than ten years, he contemplated the Buddha Dharma and mastered various scriptures.
During the Taishi period of the Liu Song Dynasty, he came to the capital and stayed at Heyuan Temple.
Since Huilong had penetrated the meaning and was good at clear discussions, he would always defeat his opponents when seizing the opportunity to argue.
Emperor Ming of the Liu Song Dynasty invited him to give a lecture on the Satyasiddhi-Å›Ästra at Xiang Palace, with more than eight hundred people carrying scriptures and seeking the Way.
Later, kings, nobles, and distinguished people repeatedly invited him to give lectures.

Wherever there were difficult and stagnant points in the old interpretations, Huilong would further reveal and expand them, making them clear and understandable. He established the meanings of real dharmas and cutting off afflictions, etc.
Zhou Yong of Runan called him:
Master Huilong is aloof and austere, like pine and bamboo under frost.
He died in the eighth year of Yongming, at the age of sixty-two.
At that time, there was Shi Zhibian in Jiangxi, who was also good at sutras and treatises. He was equal in virtue to Long. Each of them had a reputation on both sides of the river.
At that time, there were also Sengbian, Sengxian, Daohui, and Fadu in He Garden. They all studied sutras and treatises with great accomplishment.
Shi Sengzong, whose surname was Yan, was originally from Fengyi, Yongzhou.
When the Jin Dynasty was in chaos, his great-great grandfather moved to Qinjun.
At the age of nine, he became a disciple of Master Yuan and consulted him for wisdom and virtue.

He was good at the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, the ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ-sÅ«tra, the VimalakÄ«rti-nirdeÅ›a-sÅ«tra, and others.

Crown Prince Wenhui was about to banish him due to a crime, but he had a dream with a feeling, and then changed his mind and returned to him.

At the age of seven, he left home and served Huiguang of Baimasi as his teacher.

In the first year of Yongtai, he died at Zhong Temple, at the age of forty-five.
He wrote commentaries on the Vimalakirti Sutra and the Ten Grounds Sutra, as well as a five-fascicle Biography of Monks.
At that time, there were Jing Yi of Lingji Temple, Guang Zan and Hui Tao, Dao Zong of Waguan Temple, who were all famous figures of the time, admired by learners.
Shi Sengyin, whose surname was Zhu, was a person from Shouchun.
From a young age, he had a profound and discerning mind, and was diligent in learning.

Yin's precepts and conduct were pure and strict, and his nature was harmonious and gentle. He was forgiving and patient, and his joy and anger were not apparent.
At that time, those who relied on their qi, in the middle of the discussion, sometimes used it for ridicule.
Yin's spiritual appearance was peaceful, and he never had any external thoughts.
Although he studied various scriptures, he was particularly known for the Lotus Sutra. He lectured on the Lotus Sutra 252 times.
He died in the first year of Yongyuan in the Qi dynasty at the age of sixty-five.
Shi Faduo, a monk from Huanglong, left home at a young age, traveled to the north to study, and thoroughly mastered various sutras. He specialized in practicing asceticism.

At the end of the Song dynasty, he traveled to the capital city. The high-minded Qi Jun Mingseng Shao lived in seclusion beyond the world, hiding in the mountains of Langya. He admired Faduo's pure virtue and treated him with the respect of a teacher and friend.
After Shao's death, he donated the mountain where he lived to establish Xihua Monastery and invited Faduo to reside there.

After staying there for over a year, he suddenly heard the sounds of people, horses, and drums. Suddenly, a man holding a name card appeared and said to Faduo, I am Jin Shang.
Faduo went forward, and Shang's appearance was very elegant, and his feathered guards were also strict.

The Dharma Master's virtue and Way are where people return. I respectfully offer it to you and wish to receive the five precepts, forever establishing a connection for the future.
Du said:

Sheng said:
If I can provide for the disciples, I will first stop killing.
Then he took his leave.
The next morning, Du saw someone deliver ten thousand coins, incense, candles, and a knife, with a note saying:

On the fifteenth day of the month, Du held a ritual.

The mountain shrine witch dreamed that the deity said:

Once, Du was sleeping scattered on the ground, and he saw Shang coming from outside, rubbing his head and feet with his hand and leaving.
After a while, he came again, holding a glass bowl with water in it, which he offered to Du. The taste was sweet and cool, and Du's pain immediately subsided.
His responses and manifestations were like this.

They were provided with the four requisites.
He always wished to be reborn in the Pure Land, so he lectured on the Sutra of Immeasurable Life many times.
In the second year of Yongyuan of the Qi dynasty, he died in the mountains at the age of sixty-four.
Du had a disciple named Senglang, who succeeded his former teacher and again took charge of the mountain temple.

At that time, there was Huikai of Pengcheng Temple, who was naturally intelligent and had a profound understanding of learning. He therefore early gained a reputation and began lecturing at a young age.

Shi Zhizou, originally surnamed Qiu, was a person from Jingzhao who lived in Jianye.

Whenever he set up a lecture seat, the king and nobles would come to listen, carrying scriptures and following him.
He had a refined and subtle demeanor, and his thoughts penetrated the profound and subtle.
The obscure and hidden passages were all explained by him.
In the first year of Tianjian, he passed away at Zhicheng Temple at the age of 63.
On the day of the funeral, the black-robed and white-robed [monastics] rushed to the scene, filling the streets and alleys, and the officials and common people were filled with sorrow.

Sengyao recited the Lotus Sutra and was good at cursive and regular scripts, and later became the Buddhist Registry of the state of Wu.

Shi Sengsheng, Shi Sengsheng, originally surnamed He, was a person from Jianye.
